description: Come and explore the history of the Royal Docks, once a global centre of maritime trade. Recognising the impact of the decline and closure of the docks, we will look to the future and the next chapter for this special part of our city.

factsheet.heading: About the tour and guide
paragraphs: Upon opening, the Royal Docks (Royal Albert, Royal Victoria and King George V) were the largest enclosed docks in the world and were the centre of global trade. This tour will take you back, to imagine the hussle and bussle, the sights, sounds and smells of this hive of activity, where all manner of goods were shipped in from across the world, from pianos to elephants.

We will explore the stories of the people who lived and worked in the area, shaping the community and fighting for the rights of workers, a theme that is still present to this day, as the Royal Docks look to become the first London Living Wage Place.
We will culminate our tour by looking to the next chapter of for this area, exploring the potential impact of current and future regeneration.

During this 2 hour walking tour of the Royal Docks, we will make our way from the Landing Statue, celebrating the dockers and their families, onto examining some of the past remnants from the areas heyday as the global centre of trade.  We will then take a stroll along the dock edge, towards the area's newest neighbour, the Mayor of London and the GLA at City Hall. Along the way, we will explore some of the current and future regeneration projects that are shaping the next chapter of this truly special part of the city, including Millennium Mills and local water based businesses.

Access: The majority of the walk is flat and accessible. One stop on the tour includes the top of the Royal Victoria Dock bridge, via staircase. Although there is a lift, unfortunately guarantee cannot be provided about availability of use on the day.

Guide: Emma Deba-Smith works in regeneration, specialising in arts and culture, education and social value. A key focus of her work is engaging local communities with the changes taking place in their neighbourhoods.  Encouraging consultation, dialogue and ultimately co-production so that new neighbourhoods reflect and fulfil the needs of the current and future generations of communities living within them.

factsheet.heading: Golden Key Academy
paragraphs: This tour is led by a participant of Open City’s Golden Key Academy – a course training up insightful and engaging guides dedicated to explaining London and bringing its many stories to life. It is part of a wider collection of tour events created by Golden Key Academy guides for the Open House Festival celebrating their conclusion of the four month course.
Further info on the Golden Key Academy https://open-city.org.uk/golden-key-academy

factsheet.heading: Tour meeting point:
paragraphs:
Meet at the Landing Statue (outside ExCel London, see photo in listing).
Royal Victoria Dock, 1 Western Gateway
E16 1XL
